Men Who Have Died That You May Live
Martyrs to Medicine

Dr. Lazear accepted all the chances
from inoculation by the mosquito
and died five days later.
Dr. Ricketts contracted
typhus fever and died after
he discovered the body louse
carried the disease.
Dr. W.M. Wightman
died a martyr while
carrying on antiplague
work in Peru.
“Spotted-fever” caused
the death of Dr. T.B.
McClintic contracted
from the
laboratory

Dr.
Thomas B.
McClintic
Dr. Jesse W. Lazear,
Major Walter Reed
Major James Carroll.

Dr. Howard T.
Ricketts.

Fight Against Disease Has Added Many
Years to Life of Modern Man

That the work of the world's martyrs to medicine has not
been in vain is shown in the following table giving the increase
in the average duration of life:

Four hundred years ago the average duration of life was
only 21.2.
One hundred years ago it was 30 years.

Now, as a result largely of modern methods of disease
prevention, the average duration of life is 44 years.
BY DEAN HALLIDAY.

Do you know them--the men who
have died that you may live?

Reed, Carroll, Lazear, Rick-
etts, McClintic, Miller, Rich-
ardson, Wightman?

All martyrs to medicine. All men who
made mankind richer for their living and
nobler for their dying.

In history and in story the physician is
known for his self sacrifice and his de-
votion to his work, the alleviation of the
sorrow and suffering of humanity. Should
one attempt to enumerate the men who,
like Rush, have fearlessly fought the pes-
tilences that have raged from time to
time; or the men who, like Marion Sims,
have braved even popular opinion in the
accomplishment of their life work; or the
many whose lives have been sacrificed at
the bedside or in the operating room the
list would be endless.

The names listed above, however, are
of men who will always stand among the
first on the roll of Martyrs of Medicine.

The first to give up his life to the end
that man might gain control over the
dreadful scourge, yellow fever, was Dr.
Jesse W. Lazear. As one friend and ad-
mirer said of him, “He died a martyr to
science and a true hero.”

Graduating from the College of Phy-
sicians and Surgeons in New York city in
1892, Dr. Lazear went abroad to study.
Returning to this country he received his
appointment as acting assistant surgeon
in the medical department of the army in
1900 and was at once dispatched to Co-
lumbia barracks, Cuba, where he began
work as a member of the famous yellow
fever commission under the direction of
another martyr to medicine, Dr. Walter
Reed.

Lazear observed cases of yellow fever,
made autopsies, took cultures and studied
blood-films with the result that by the
time Dr. Reed and his co-worker, Dr.
James Carroll, reached Cuba some months
later he was ready to say with confidence
that cultures and blood examinations
promised nothing in the prevention of the
disease.

Attention was then given the mosquito
as being the insect responsible for the
spread of yellow fever and Dr. Lazear
was placed in charge of this work. On
August 11, 1900, Dr. Lazear made the first
mosquito experiment. He made nine in-
oculations on persons, including himself,
but this work was without results.

A month later, however, while at Las
Animas hospital, for the purpose of col-
lecting blood from yellow fever patients, a
mosquito alighted on his hand.

He allowed it to take its fill of his
blood, although at the time, Dr. Lazear
did not believe the mosquito to be one
of the Culex Fasciatus, the species be-
lieved to be responsible for transmitting
the germs of yellow fever.

However, he voluntarily accepted all
the chances that went with this inocula-
tion and five days later he had his first
warning of approaching disease and death
in a severe attack of chills.

Instead of taking immediate measures
to protect himself he seized on the op-
portunity to use himself as a test case in
the interest of science. All that night he
spent writing up the experiments in re-
gard to yellow fever and the mosquito in-
oculations, making notes from time to
time of his own case, of which no rec-
ord had been made.

Early the next morning he handed over
his precious material to Dr. Carroll and
was then rushed to the hospital with a
temperature of 103. Six days later he
died from the fever.

His life was sacrificed when the great
work was scarcely begun, yet, as Dr.
Reed said, “Dr. Lazear's efforts in this
work were of vast importance.”

Dr. James Carroll, co-worker with Reed
and Lazear, was the first man to contract
yellow fever experimentally from the bite
of an infected mosquito.

After serving in the army as private,
corporal, sergeant, and later in the med-
ical corps, he joined Reed and Lazear in
Cuba in 1900 as a member of the yellow
fever commission.

For the sake of the great work he was
engaged in, he allowed himself to be bit-
ten by a mosquito infected with yellow
fever, on August 27, 1900, and was taken
sick four days later. He had a very se-
vere attack. Although he recovered at
the time a serious heart trouble, myocar-
ditis, followed as a direct result of the
yellow fever. Dr. Carroll suffered from
this for the rest of his life and it eventu-
ally caused his death, September 16, 1907.

Another famous martyr to medicine
was Dr. Walter Reed, who was the mas-
ter mind in the work of solving the prob-
lems of yellow fever. It was Reed, who
as the head of the yellow fever commis-
sion of 1900 quickly saw that this disease
must be transmitted by some insect, prob-
ably the mosquito, as suggested by a Dr.
Finlay.

After studying the problem Reed and
his co-workers concluded that the results,
if positive, would be of sufficient service
to humanity to justify the experimental
use of human beings. The committee also
agreed that it was their duty to run the
first risk with the result that Drs. Car-
roll and Lazear met their deaths as pre-
viously told.

After starting their experiments,
Reed wrote to his wife, “just eighteen
days from the time we began our ex-
perimental work, we have succeeded in
demonstrating that mosquitoes do
spread the disease, so that the most
doubtful and skeptical must believe.
* * * Ah, wonderful is nature,
and I thank God that he has allowed
poor unworthy me to look a little way
into this secret.”

And again he wrote, “ The prayer that
has been mine for twenty years, that it
might be permitted in some way at
some time to do something to alleviate
human suffering, has been granted.”

In February, 1901, after his work in
Cuba was finished, Reed returned to
Washington and resumed his teaching
in the Army Medical school. He was
also professor of pathology and bac-
teriology at Columbia university.

But in 1902, when he returned to his
work, it was evident that his strength
was far below par. The day's work was
too much for him. All mental exertion
was a painful effort.

On November 17, 1902, he was oper-
ated on for appendicitis, and then the
overwork and anxiety borne during his
work in fighting yellow fever had their
effect, for he failed to rally properly
from the operation, and a few days
later, November 23, 1902, he died.

He was a martyr who at least had
the satisfaction of finishing his work,
and that it was a great work is best
set forth by General Leonard Wood, who
says:

“I know of no other man on this side
of the world who has done so much for
humanity as Dr. Walter Reed. His dis-
covery results in the saving of more
lives annually than were lost in the
Cuban war, and saves the commercial
interests of the world a greater finan-
cial loss each year than the cost of the
Cuban war.”

The armies at war in Europe, with
the possible exception of the Serbian,
have escaped in a miraculous manner,
the ravages of dread typhus fever. That
they have been able to adequately
guard against the disease is greatly due
to the martyrdom of Dr. Howard T.
Ricketts, who demonstrated that typhus
fever is carried by the body louse.

Ricketts was one of the most notable
research workers of this country. In
1907, after tireless work in Montana, to
find the cause and prevention of Rocky
mountain spotted fever, he proved that
the disease was spread by the tick. In
showing how to check the spread of this
disease by the extermination of ticks by
dipping domestic stock in an arsenical
solution, and by killing off small wild
animals that harbored the insects,
Ricketts was not only saving the lives
of a number of persons each year, but
was checking a disease which had be-
gun to spread throughout the entire
west and into Canada also.

This work done, Ricketts went to
Mexico City to study typhus fever. But
in experiments in which he proved that
the disease is carried by the body louse,
he contracted the very disease he was
combating, and died May 3 , 1910.

In his death “on the firing line,” the
country lost an investigator of the first
rank, whose name through his achieve-
ments in investigating “spotted” and
typhus fever will live in the history of
medical science.

A second worker in Rocky mountain
spotted fever to die on the “firing line”
was Thomas B. McClintic, a passed as-
sistant surgeon of the United States
public health and marine hospital serv-
ice.

In 1911 he was sent into the Bitter
Root valley, where Rocky mountain
spotted fever raged, to put into practice
the theories regarding the disease and
its prevention advanced by Dr. Ricketts.
This meant ridding the valley of ticks.

In 1912 McClintic had made progress
with his work, but just as he finished
the season's work he contracted “spot-
ted” fever, probably from the labora-
tory. He lived only six days. As soon
as he knew that he had this disease, he
returned to Washington, where he died
August 13, 1912.

Dr. Ricketts had taught us how
Rocky mountain spotted fever could be
controlled. Dr. McClintic gave us the
practical demonstration of these teach-
ings.

Still another fearless scientist who
gave his life that mankind might be
better protected against disease was Dr.
William Whitfield Miller, an assistant
surgeon in the United States public
health and marine hospital service. He
died in Washington, D. C., November
24, 1908, of typhoid fever, contracted
during experiments in the laboratory.

At the time of his death, Dr. Miller
was actively engaged in studying the
origin and prevalence of typhoid fever
in the District of Columbia. He had
been working with a large number of
specimens of typhoid material, having
taken up this task at the suggestion of
President Roosevelt.

At the International Sanitary Conven-
tion of the American Republics, which
was held in October, 1905, an agreement
was provided between these republics
concerning the quarantine treatment of
yellow fever.

It was considered necessary to thor-
oughly protect all the southern ports of
the United States, as well as the ports
of our southern neighbors, from the in-
vasion of yellow fever, and it was agreed
that measures should be taken to elimin-
ate from all ports the conditions which
tend to produce this disease.

The government of Honduras asked
the secretary of state of the United
States for the services of a competent
medical officer to take charge of the
sanitation, particularly of the depart-
ment of Cortez, in the interest, more es-
pecially, of the fruit trade in that dis-
trict.

Accordingly, Passed Assistant Surgeon
T. F. Richardson, distinguished for his
work against yellow fever, was put at
the service of the Honduras government.
On his way to Puerto, Cortez, however,
he was stricken with typhoid fever, and
died in New Orleans, March 19, 1906,
thus giving another life in the health
service of his country.

Following Richardson came Dr. Wil-
liam Martin Wightman, who, during
1906-08, was stationed at Callao, Peru,
where he carried on antiplague work.
After this he was sent to Guayaquil,
Ecuador, to observe and take measures
for preventing the spread of yellow fever.

But the fever got him first, and he
died in Guayaquil, May 16, 1909 at the
died in Guayaquil, May 16, 1909, at the
age of thirty-three. Thus one more sol-
dier was taken from the “firing line”
and one more martyr added to the list
for which yellow fever is responsible.

It was only five years ago in this
country that a woman's name was added
to the list of those who have met death
in trying to defeat disease. She
was Dr. Emma W. Mooers, graduate of
the University of Michigan, curator of
the neuropathological department at
Harvard Medical School, and the assist-
ant of Dr. Southard.

While examining the tissues of a man
who had died from septic tonsilitis as
part of their experiments, both Dr.
Mooers and Dr. Southard became in-
fected.

Dr. Southard, while very ill, recov-
ered, but Dr. Mooers had streptococcus
poisoning from which she died, May 1,
1911.

At the time she became fatally in-
fected, Dr. Mooers was searching for the
cause of a widspread epidemic of viru-
lent tonsilitis which had been present in
Boston and vicinity, and she was trying
to gain information in regard to the
means necessary to check the epidemic.

Day and night the war against pre-
ventable disease goes on. Time and
time again some one drops on the “firing
line,” and another takes their place.
Each one, like Reed, lives in the hope
that some day they will be able to do
something for humanity. Some, like
Reed, live to accomplish their object,
others pave the way, but are stricken
before they have reached their goal.

An officer of the United States public
health service gives the following list of
medical officers of the service who have
died in studying and combating dis-
ease

Seventeen men, while on quarantine
duty, contracted yellow fever. Five of
these men died: Glozier, Waldo, Groen-
velt, McAdam and Wightman.

Eleven contracted tuberculosis in line
of duty, and of these three died: Pro-
chazka, Decker and Devan.

Four contracted amoebic dysentery in
the Philippines. One of these men is
permanently disabled.

Five contracted typhoid fever from
direct exposure on field duty or in the
laboratory. Of these, two, Miller and
Richardson, died.

Two contracted smallpox in line of
duty. One contracted typhus fever in
Mexico. Two contracted cholera in line
of duty. One died of Rocky mountain
spotted fever.

During the period covered by these
figures, the corps varied from 65 to 135
and the average was 100--a brave hand-
ful of men fighting always to save the
lives of others, and when necessary, giv-
ing their own lives to that end.
Is it worth it?

A large proportion of the diseases
from which mankind suffers today are
preventable. The time will come when
such diseases as yellow fever and
malaria will belong only to the ancient
history of medicine.

All work, no matter how trivial or
valueless it may seem, if it has been
done with honesty of purpose, has its
place in the great victory over pain and
pestilence.

Were it possible to ask those who
have fought in this cause and died for
it, “Was it worth while?” they, too,
would say that they rejoiced that
they had not lived in vain, but had been
allowed a little share in the work of
alleviating the suffering of humanity.
